comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The U. S. was naturally uneasy at the thought of Japanese military materiel (and personnel) being placed close to its southern border, but President Wilson issued a statement that the activity of the Japanese with respect to the Huerta regime had been scrupulously correct, and a day later the Mexican regime (this was during the armed conflicts of the Mexican Revolution) stated that it would not accept foreign military assistance of any kind. Story in the New York Times, January 31, 1914: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D04E1DA1730E733A...
